ClassificationScheme.Note: This list has been updated and partly reorganised

Term.Name: No sound
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 1/0 (Mono)
Term.Definition: Single Monographic Sound. A system using a single discrete audio channel (Monophonic). Also called monaural.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Dual mono
Term.Definition: The same monaural signal is replicated on both channels.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 2/0 (Stereo)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 2/0 (Stereo) + LFE
Term.Definition: Stereographic Sound plus Low Frequency Effects.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stereo International
Term.Definition: Stereographic Sound plus two single monographic sounds for commentaries.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stereo A and B
Term.Definition: A system using two discrete audio channels, typically derived from two transducers geographically separated, to give slightly different audio perspective of the same event.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stereo M and S
Term.Definition: A system using two discrete audio channels, typically derived from two transducers geographically separated, to give slightly different audio perspective of the same event.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Multi-lingual
Term.Definition: A channel configuration allowing the support of more than one language
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Surround
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 5.1 Surround
Term.Definition: A system comprising five discrete, full range main channels (Left, Centre, Right, Left surround, Right surround) plus a band-limited Low Frequency Effects channel: 3/2/1 (L,C,R, LSide, RSide). This is used in Home Theater systems
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: 7.1 Surround
Term.Definition: An eight-channel surround audio system. It adds two additional speakers to the more conventional six-channel (5.1) audio configuration. As with 5.1 surround sound, 7.1 surround sound positional audio uses the standard front, center, and LFE (subwoofer) speaker configuration. This is used in Movie Theater systems.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: 10.2 Surround
Term.Definition: 10.2 surround sound would add four more channels to the front listening area and only one surround channel.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: 22.2 Surround
Term.Definition: The surround sound component of Super Hi-Vision developed by NHK STRL and using 22 + 2 LFE speakers.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: Multi-channel
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 2/1 (Multi-channel)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 2/2 (Multi-channel)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 3/0 (Multi-channel)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 3/1 (Multi-channel)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 3/2 (Multi-channel)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: 3/2 (Multi-channel) + LFE
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: Ambisonics
Term.Definition: A series of recording and replay techniques using multichannel mixing technology that can be used live or in the studio and which recreates the soundfield as it existed in the space, in contrast to traditional surround systems, which can only create illusion of the soundfield if the listener is located in a very narrow sweetspot between speakers.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: Panor-Ambiophonic (PanAmbio) 4.0/4.1
Term.Definition: Combines a stereo dipole and crosstalk cancellation in front and a second set behind the listener (total of four speakers) for 360Â° 2D surround reproduction. Four channel recordings, especially those containing binaural cues, create speaker-binaural surround sound. 5.1 channel recordings, including movie DVDs, are compatible by mixing C-channel content to the front speaker pair. 6.1 can be played by mixing SC to the back pair.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: Object audio
Term.Definition: Audio following a structure following the the Audio Definition Model (ADM), specifies how XML metadata can be generated to provide the definitions of tracks in an audio file.
Term.ChangeComment: Update

Term.Name: Other
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML
